title: 113_hr1929
content: The Act titled "Enhancing Employment and Training Through Education Act of 2013" aims to implement pilot projects to reduce dependency and increase work effort in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include pilot projects aimed at increasing work effort and reducing dependency in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. The Act includes pilot projects to improve employment and training programs, increase work registrants' earnings, and reduce reliance on public assistance, such as the supplemental nutrition assistance program. Pilot projects will be selected based on criteria set by the Secretary, including enhancing existing programs and agreeing to participate in evaluations. The pilot projects aim to enhance employment and training programs, evaluate participants' outcomes, and collaborate with the State workforce board. The pilot projects aim to enhance employment and training programs by agreeing to participate in evaluations, collaborating with the State workforce board, and ensuring replicability. Additional criteria may also be considered. The pilot projects aim to enhance employment and training programs by targeting various populations of work registrants and ensuring replicability. The pilot projects target different populations of work registrants and are selected from various existing employment and training programs. Existing employment and training programs include section 20 workfare, skills development for work registrants with limited employment history, post-employment support services, and education leading to a recognized postsecondary credential. Existing employment and training programs include post-employment support services necessary for maintaining employment, education leading to a recognized postsecondary credential, registered apprenticeship, or secondary school diploma or its equivalent, and are located in various geographic areas. The Secretary will evaluate pilot projects selected under this subsection to measure their impact on participants with recognized credentials in diverse geographic areas. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation of pilot projects to assess their impact on participants' ability to find and retain employment, leading to increased household income and reduced dependency. A report to Congress is due by September 30, 2017. The Secretary will evaluate pilot projects to measure their impact on participants' ability to find and retain employment, leading to increased household income and reduced dependency. A report to Congress is due by September 30, 2017. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress by September 30, 2017, detailing the results and costs of pilot projects, including their impact on employment, income, and public benefit receipt of work registrants. Planned dissemination of the reports will also be included. The evaluation of pilot projects will include the impact on employment, income, and public benefit receipt of work registrants, as well as the costs, dissemination of findings, and steps to incorporate successful components into state programs. Funding will be allocated from available amounts. The Secretary will allocate $10,000,000 annually from available funds for pilot projects that demonstrate increased employment and earnings. These funds will be used exclusively for this purpose. The Secretary will allocate $10,000,000 annually for pilot projects that comply with the provisions of the Act, cover project costs and administration, and provide necessary information and data. The Secretary will allocate $10,000,000 annually for pilot projects that comply with the provisions of the Act, cover project costs and administration, provide necessary information and data, and fund the evaluation costs.
